Posts.Content: Susan, you may find that you didn't like hats with your hair but without hair they may look totally different. I was never a hat person either but I wear either a headwrap (purchased at www.4women.com) or a ball cap or bucket hat. The hats have a totally different look without hair. Good luck and I hope you find something to your satisfaction.
Posts.Title: Starting Taxol

Posts.Content: Carol, I don't comment too much on posts these days, but I always check in on a few pink sisters, like YOU.  You have been through so much and always with your typical positive attitude.  Only you can make the decision on what to do and I get the feeling that those are well thought through by you.  I have been dealing with my Stage IV dx since August 2010.  I have been on chemo, Abraxane and Eribulin, since that dx.  I had to be taken off the Eribulin due to severe neoropathy in my feet and legs.  My onco next recommended Xeloda.  I have been on it for a short time, only on week 2 right now.  I was very apprehensive about taking this one due to the "hand and foot syndrome" side effect.  I have to report, so far so good.  I may have a little redness in my hands but I am not certain if that's from wringing them or from the chemo.  I have an appointment this afternoon and will find out.  The best part is my hair is coming back in and I will hopefully get to ditch the scarves in a couple of months!! Take care of yourself and I'll check back in on your progress later. Enjoy your new found taste buds and improving quality of life! (((Hugs))), Debbie
Posts.Title: Latest MRI...

Posts.Content: Debbie, they say it is cumulative but I think it varies from person to person. I really didn't notice much difference until my last treatment. I was not taking the same chemo drugs, I was on taxotere and cytoxan. Good luck tomorrow and look at it that your one step closer to the finish line.
Posts.Title: C&A

Posts.Content: Carol, I don't comment too much on posts these days, but I always check in on a few pink sisters, like YOU.  You have been through so much and always with your typical positive attitude.  Only you can make the decision on what to do and I get the feeling that those are well thought through by you.  I have been dealing with my Stage IV dx since August 2010.  I have been on chemo, Abraxane and Eribulin, since that dx.  I had to be taken off the Eribulin due to severe neoropathy in my feet and legs.  My onco next recommended Xeloda.  I have been on it for a short time, only on week 2 right now.  I was very apprehensive about taking this one due to the "hand and foot syndrome" side effect.  I have to report, so far so good.  I may have a little redness in my hands but I am not certain if that's from wringing them or from the chemo.  I have an appointment this afternoon and will find out.  The best part is my hair is coming back in and I will hopefully get to ditch the scarves in a couple of months!! Take care of yourself and I'll check back in on your progress later. Enjoy your new found taste buds and improving quality of life! (((Hugs))), Debbie
Posts.Title: Latest MRI...

Posts.Content: I had a bone density test last Thursday and just received the call from my onco's office telling me I have osteoporosis and I needed to get an apppointment with my PCP to discuss treatment. I wasn't actually talking with the onco but one of the office staff and asked the question "what about continuing the Arimidex"? I know one of the side effects of this is osteoporosis. Anyone out there taking Arimidex and also been diagnosed with osteoporosis? If so, what are you doing for the osteoporosis? I'll wait to hear from my sisters. Thanks for any input. In the meantime, I'll also make the call to my PCP.
Posts.Title: Osteoporosis diagnosis

Posts.Content: Tara, I'm sorry you had to come back here but so happy that you knew this site existed. It has been a godsend at times and the members are incredible. I don't have any experience regarding sarcomas but wanted to acknowledge your post. As you know, you have come to the right place. Please continue to post and let us know your outcome. Take care.
Posts.Title: Here I am again

Posts.Content: Jeanne, what a sweet picture!! You look so happy, too.
Posts.Title: New Challenge for you

Posts.Content: Penny, sending positive thoughts your way for successful surgeries and quick recovery. Keep us posted on your progress.
Posts.Title: surgery next wednesday

Posts.Content: Susan, I'm so sorry to read this news. I have to wonder what is happening now, there are so many sisters with recurrences. I hope you get your consultation this week and get an idea of your treatment. We are here for you. Sending strength, love and (((hugs)))!!
Posts.Title: Monday's Biopsy Results

Posts.Content: I'll be sending positive thoughts your way as well. Best of luck for a successful outcome! Hang in there and "fight like a girl" (I love that saying too)!!
Posts.Title: Tomorrow's the "Day" (10--21-09)

Posts.Content: Meena, I am so happy to read this but I have to ask, how did I miss this? I would have happily participated for such a wonderful kindred spirit. Oh well, it's the thoughts that count and I have certainly thought about you often. Take care and fight on!!
Posts.Title: A big Thank You!!!!

Posts.Content: Okay, I'm going to go ahead and show my age and ask "what are you all talking about"? I don't see any +'s or -'s by anyone's name. Help!!
Posts.Title: What does the + sign mean next to all of your names?

Posts.Content: Thanks, Margo. I had to put my reading glasses on to see it. I can't tell a lie, I never noticed it before. Age, it's a wonderful thing!! Or, I should say, reading glasses are a wonderful thing!! LOL.
Posts.Title: What does the + sign mean next to all of your names?

Posts.Content: Great picture, tj. Now, I'll go look for one for me. This is fun!!
Posts.Title: New Challenge for you

Posts.Content: Your First Communion, I would guess???? I have one just like it, if that's the case.
Posts.Title: New Challenge for you

Posts.Content: I'm a little late with my reply, but yes, buzz it. I, too, didn't actually shave my head but buzzed it instead. Beings that I am so late, did you shave or buzz your head, Tracy? If so, doesn't it feel better? Let us know. Good luck!!
Posts.Title: Does head soreness go away after hair comes out?? (hopefully??)

Posts.Content: Kathy, that is such sad news. I'm so sorry and will definately keep you and his family in my thoughts. He was simply taken too young and way too soon!! I hate cancer and just wish there was a cure on the horizon to spare the pain and suffering of children such as Carter. Sending a (((HUG))) your way. Take care.
Posts.Title: Sorry to post such bad news

Posts.Content: Hi, Pat, I'm at the beaches of Jacksonville, Orange Park is across the river. I have a wonderful surgeon and oncologist but they are located in Jacksonville Beach. That would be approximately a 45 minute drive from Orange Park, depending on where in Orange Park you are. There are several ladies on this site that are triple negative. I am not one of them. What I have learned is that this type of bc is more aggressive. I think it's a good idea that you are having it treated before your trip. Let me know if I can help further with any information regarding doctors. Good luck to you!!
Posts.Title: Trying to Find an Oncologist in Orange Park FL

Posts.Content: Other than being lonely and feeling like an outcast (LOL), what's the advantage/disadvantage of having "friends"?
Posts.Title: What does the + sign mean next to all of your names?

Posts.Content: I hope you have a fabulous trip and I can't wait to hear the details. Also, can't wait to hear what your very special painting looks like. Have fun!!
Posts.Title: Change on weekend plans!!

Posts.Content: Re, it sounds like an absolutely wonderful time. You so deserve this great surprise! I love San Francisco, too!
Posts.Title: Surprise Plans for my upcoming cancerversary

Posts.Content: Hi, Patty and welcome to this wonderful group of amazing prople. We have one very brave member, Different Ballgame, that is on Weight Watchers and actually posts an update weekly. Perhaps that could be the start of looking for a buddy. Good luck and it's always encouraging to read about survivors and you are one. Take care.
Posts.Title: I need to lose weight and need a support group

Posts.Content: Susan, while your treatment is not ideal, it is better than what could have been. I am happy to read that you get to have fun mixed in with the dreaded rads. I know you had a wonderful time celebrating your dad's 80th (I hope you get to celebrate your 80th, too). Enjoy your high school reunion. I attended my 10th and had a great time. I had to get out my yearbook before the reunion to hopefully remember some classmates. There were over 600 in my graduating class. I am hoping for an easy time for you and if that can't be, then at least something tolerable. Sending love and (((hugs)).
Posts.Title: Last Week & This Week & Next Week

Posts.Content: I can't imagine how scary that must be for a young child. I'm sending hugs and prayers for Carter. He's way too young to have to go through this, I hate cancer!!!
Posts.Title: Prayers for Carter

Posts.Content: Very, very cute. I was wondering what some of his answers were going to be towards the end. Thanks for the chuckle.
Posts.Title: Final exam....

Posts.Content: Cindy Ann, welcome to this amazing group!! I think your decision to meet with the surgeon and express your concerns is the right thing to do. You are just in the beginning phase of treatment and may have additional treatments once surgery is completed. It is very normal to "feel lost" when we are first diagnosed. I immediately went on line to obtain as much information as I could. I had experienced cancer in my life but not breast cancer and therefore I needed knowledge. Shame on that nurse for scolding you. She's the one that needs a lesson in "how to treat people". I'm glad you found us and please ask as many questions as you have and someone on here will have knowledge to share. Take care.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnoised with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Cat, a gigantic THANK YOU from the bottom of my heart!! You are truly one of a kind to include ALL of us in your walk. I will do my local walk in October and will take all of you with me, too.
Posts.Title: *******THANK YOU CATS TOY!*******

Posts.Content: JD, the important one here right now is YOU. We do all have to make concessions in our lives as we go through our treatments. Truth be known, you probably shouldn't be in a crowd of people that large anyway. Is there a chance that someone has a video camera and can record the event for you? I know I wouldn't want to miss my daughter's graduation but if it was between my health or the ceremony, I'd have to chose my health. I'm very certain that your son will understand and would probably make the same choice. I'm sorry that you have to miss something as important as this. It's not every day that our children graduate. Good luck and deep down I'm hoping that you have a surge of energy and are able to enjoy the ceremony in person. Take care.
Posts.Title: My son is graduating

Posts.Content: We have a boutique here called "In The Pink" that is geared toward bc women. The owner has recently started a class called Laughology and guarantees plenty of laughter. I have received the invitations but have to admit I haven't attended yet. I may have to try one out because I really do believe that laughter is good for our bodies. The flyer that is sent out has the comment that "laughing for one minute is equivalent to ten minutes of aerobic exercise…..no joke!". So, just imagine an entire weekend....we'd all be bikini babes.
Posts.Title: Kids Will Be Kids~ Friday Funny! :-)

Posts.Content: I picked you out immediately based on your previous photo. It's nice to meet your sisters, too. Thanks for sharing.
Posts.Title: Sisters

Posts.Content: Hi, Melody. I previously used Hospice when my husband was terminally ill with mesotheliomia. They are typically called in, if requested, when the patient has a prognosis of 6 months or less to live. I do know that pain management is one of their services. My experience with them was 20 years ago and it's very possible that their requirements and services they offer have changed over all the years. Good luck with your mom and I hope she does get any pain she is experiencing under control. Take care.
Posts.Title: Hospice Care for Pain Management

Posts.Content: TulsaMom, I would recommend that you take someone with you to your appointment. You will be given so much information and it's almost impossible to remember everything you are told. At least if someone else is there they can help take notes too. Or, maybe you can take a recorder along, I know several sisters here have done that. Good luck on making your decision once you have all the information. If we can help in anyway, just ask. Take care.
Posts.Title: First Oncology appointment/ What to expect?

Posts.Content: Ha-ha!! Thanks for the chuckle!!
Posts.Title: 2009's First Christmas Joke--you may have already seen this.

Posts.Content: Jean, I wanted to welcome you to this amazing site. I hope this proves to be a wealth of knowledge for you like it was for me. I didn't notice much difference from my first chemo treatment until my last one. I took the same drugs you are taking. It does sound like you are doing fairly well tolerating the drugs. Good luck and continue to ask questions as they arise.
Posts.Title: What do I expect after next treatments?

Posts.Content: That's great news, MamaG. I sure hope this does the trick and you are back dancing in no time. You are a true warrior and an inspiration to many. Take care and keep bringing us the good news!!
Posts.Title: Cyberknife was a BREEZE!!

Posts.Content: Congratulations on achieving such a milestone. I LOVE to read about marriages that last a lifetime. I'm a romantic at heart and enjoyed sharing your joy. Wishing you both many, many more joyous and healthy years together!!
Posts.Title: Had a good time.

Posts.Content: Kathi, I will be thinking of you tonight and wishing for a quiet evening for you to remember your daughter. Thanks for sharing a part of your life with us!
Posts.Title: Tomorrow (tonight) is a bit tough....

Posts.Content: Libby, your determination and beauty shines through in your picture!! I am always amazed at your strength. You are one of the bravest sisters on this board. I'll be with you tomorrow and wishing you success. Take care of yourself!!
Posts.Title: New expressions

Posts.Content: Thanks, Chen. I had seen this one before but I think I laughed even harder the second time and out loud, too. Laughter really is the best medicine.
Posts.Title: Kids Will Be Kids~ Friday Funny! :-)

Posts.Content: Thomas, your news is so sad but I am happy to read that Lesley is at home and surrounded by her family. I will continue to hope for some improvement and perhaps a miracle. You are a very dedicated spouse and I just wish that everyone having to fight this beast had the same situation. Continue to make the lasting memories while you have time. My heart breaks for your children because it is so hard for them to understand. Even though we have never met you or Lesley in person, you are all a part of this family. Sending strength to you for the coming days. Take care.
Posts.Title: Lesley is home

Posts.Content: I am also a dog lover and totally understand your heartbreak. Our JRT, Turbo, is 11 years old and was my constant companion while I was going through tx. Just as soon as my husband arrived home, Turbo quickly shifted all attention to him. I'm glad that you have Bear with you to help with some of the sorrow. Sending (((hugs))) to you.
Posts.Title: My Beautiful Angel died

Posts.Content: Cindy, you are on the same chemo cocktail I was on and my hair loss was almost identical to yours. What I did when it got to the scraggly look was to buzz it all again. At least then it was all the same length. I have been done with chemo since 10/15 and my hair is coming back in nicely. It's about 3/4 of an inch long. I still wear my scarves to work but go without when I'm home. That's really nothing new, I've done that the entire time. I guess the bottom line is to do whatever is most comfortable to you. Best of luck!!
Posts.Title: How long did it take for your hair to totally fall out?

Posts.Content: I did very well with minimal side effects. I worked through treatments. I took my treatments on Thursday's and took Thursday and Friday off from work. I also received the Nuelasta shot the day after chemo. I probably had worse side effects from it than I did from chemo...basically some bone pain around day 3. I controlled the pain with Tylenol every 6 hours. I did lose my hair around day 14 from the first transfusion. That, to me, was the hardest part of the chemo. I continued to exercise a minimum of 3 days and usually 5 days per week. I do Jazzercise which is an aerobic workout that includes strength training. My oncologist said I probably did so well because I did exercise. Who knows. We are all different but we are all getting through this and slaying the beast. I wish you well and I know it's tough to make the decision. Only you can do it. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Finding someone with similar dx

Posts.Content: I am also a dog lover and totally understand your heartbreak. Our JRT, Turbo, is 11 years old and was my constant companion while I was going through tx. Just as soon as my husband arrived home, Turbo quickly shifted all attention to him. I'm glad that you have Bear with you to help with some of the sorrow. Sending (((hugs))) to you.
Posts.Title: My Beautiful Angel died

Posts.Content: Sending Irishwhispers a huge supply of strength and positiveness to once again beat the beast. We'll be with you every step of the way. Take care!!
Posts.Title: Regarding Irishwhispers

Posts.Content: Welcome, linpsu. You have gotten response from some of our warriors and some of them have fought the fight more than once. I have just recently finished my treatments for my first, and I hope last, fight with the beast. I had chemo (Cytoxan/Taxotere) and rads. I do want to reassure you that the chemo today is not what it was years ago. Yes, there are some side effects but they vary from person to person. I had minimal side effects from it. Keep us posted and we'll be there with you through your treatments. Good luck and sending a (((hug)))) your way.
Posts.Title: BC reoccurence

Posts.Content: Laurissa, I'll be thinking about you tomorrow and wishing for the best possible results. You are a fighter and a very determined lady. One day at a time! Sending strength and (((hugs)). Love you.
Posts.Title: Liver catscan results on Monday

Posts.Content: Sending prayers your way for you and your daughter. Also, sending strength to help in getting through the situation. Take care!
Posts.Title: prayers for my daughter

Posts.Content: You have found the most amazing group of individuals to help you through treatments. Do you know what type of chemo you are going to have and how often? Like my other sisters have said the good news is they "got it all". Glad you found this site and please know that there is almost always someone here to answer your questions or just listen to your post. Good luck to you and look forward to getting to know you better. Take care.
Posts.Title: They say they got it all But..........

Posts.Content: I'm not surprised though. I have learned so much from this site and am so thankful that I found it, too. I always mention this site to anyone that will listen. Thanks for sharing this wonderful information and also for ALL you wonderful CSNers.
Posts.Title: During a chat with the National Cancer Institute....

Posts.Content: If I'm not mistaken, a side effect of both of these drugs is hair loss. Mine started coming out in around 14 days. At first it was just shedding pretty bad and then it really started coming out in the shower and when I combed my hair. I had it shaved on a Friday to give me time to get used to it over the weekend. I have had 3 treatments so far with one more to go. I have been lucky in that I have not experienced any nausua. I do experience bone pain about 3-4 days after the Nuelasta shot but I can control it with Tylenol. Other than that, I really don't have negative side effects. I may just be one of the lucky ones. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Chemo cocktail ,taxottere,cytoxan

Posts.Content: Hi, Mesa, and welcome. My dx was almost identical to yours and included the microscopic cell in the lymph node. I wasn't given a choice of whether or not I should take chemo. My oncologist stated that it was a part of her recommended treatment. I did 4 taxotere/cytoxan infusions and am currently doing 34 radiation treatments. Then, I will take, more than likely, Arimidex for 5 years. It has all been very doable. Good luck in making your decision. It is a very personal decision and must be made by YOU. Take care and keep in touch with us here.
Posts.Title: Finding someone with similar dx

Posts.Content: Hello sweet sisters. I haven't been posting a lot lately but that doesns't mean that I have not been on here checking on all of you. Well, as my subject line says, I am AGAIN going to go head to head with the beast. This is the third time in 3 years. This time, I am going to Mayo Clinic to get a second opinion. Who am I kidding, I'm thinking very strongly of switching my care to them. I have an appointment with them next Tuesday. I have been busy getting all my records, scans, path reports, etc. sent to them. They have a large breast cancer research center here in Jacksonville. I received the results from the needle core biopsy last Friday. I have to admit I was surprised but not shocked. I found a lump on the scar line several months ago. I am pissed off at my plastic surgeon because I brought this to his attention and inquired if it was perhaps scar tissue (you know how we like to think of anything other than the big "C"). He kind of brushed it off and agreed with me. He was never my favorite of doctors because I always felt his bedside manner skills were lacking. He is more interested in the plastic part of his job and not so much into the actual person. I am pissed at myself too because I have found my last two lumps and should have been more proactive. But, after all, he is the medical doctor, not me! I am certain the outcome would have been the same, I would again be diagnosed with IDC but perhaps the treatment may not have been so invasive. I met with my previous surgeon on Monday of this week and if she were going to treat me, it would involve removing the implant, surgery, radiation and chemotherapy. She said the radiation would destroy the latissimus muscle that was moved forward after my bilateral mastectomy and so IF I was going to consider reconstruction again, my choice would be either the LAT Flap or Diep Flap. Both surgeries are very extensive and approximately 10 hours long. I won't know until I go to Mayo what they recommend but I am definately not going through that type of surgery again. So, I will keep you updated as I learn my new path down this road again. I know that I can and will get through this again and what makes that a little easier is ALL of YOU!! Love you and sending hugs, Debbie P.S. Thought of changing my name to MyTurnAGAIN!!
Posts.Title: Pink Gloves On - Back in the ring for Round 3!!

Posts.Content: Wishing you a special day with family and friends. Enjoy the cake, ice cream and ALL those presents. I am also wishing you many, many years of health and happiness!!
Posts.Title: Today is LadyG's Birthday!

Posts.Title: Pink Gloves On - Back in the ring for Round 3!!

Posts.Content: Shortscake, I'm sorry to read that you have been given more to deal with. I'm sending strength and (((hugs))) your way to hopefully help in your struggles. Crying is a good thing as it helps relieve the pent up stress. You are a strong lady and we are here to help you through your treatments. Let us know how it goes today with your chemo. Take care and GIRL POWER!!!!
Posts.Title: back to chemo on Monday 5/10/10

Posts.Content: Nancy, I'm putting my money on the rads to do the trick. You have a great attitude and are so lucky to be surrounded by your loving husband, family and of course, all of us. Now, with that being said, go kick that cancer right in the arse! Sending love and (((hugs))).
Posts.Title: The new plan...I flunked out of the clinical trial....lol

Posts.Content: Sending strength your way to help your dear friend. 10 years is a long time to fight this damn disease. My heart goes out to you both. (((Hugs)))
Posts.Title: Benefit for a friend, need prayers

Posts.Content: Sending ((((hugs)))) right back at you all!! Sue, thanks for echoing my thoughts, you do it so well! Love you all.
Posts.Title: Do you want to know something sisters in pink?

Posts.Content: Sunrae, I'm sending positive thoughts and strength your way. I, too, hope the powers to be can do whatever it takes to have you feeling better and ready for that surgery. Keep us posted and best of luck to you!! ((((HUGS)))) on the way, too!!!
Posts.Title: Feeling Bad but Looking forward to Heart Cath Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday!! What a wonderful surprise for your birthday.....sharing it with your children. Enjoy your time together!
Posts.Title: Best Birthday Surprise!!

Posts.Content: Hi, Pammy, it is soooo good to see you back. I'm sorry to read that you are "full of poop", LOL. I will be hoping that they discover the culprit and take care of it post haste. Maybe you just need a little more time of being off the Arimidex. I'll keep my fingers crossed that that's the case. Take care of yourself and don't be a stranger.
Posts.Title: Flank pain....

Posts.Content: Sue, I did my first (and only) walk last year. I was in the beginning of rads at the time. It was a very emotional situation and especially the survivors photo. I was so astounded that there were so many survivors. That really is a very good thing!! Our walk was on the beach and there was no survivors walk just the photo. I was proud to be a part of the photo and to also raise money to help towards finding a cure. If you can't walk, I'm sure that hubby of yours will carry you around the track in his arms. He truly is a wonderful man and I'm sure he'll provide the support you need. You are a survivor. You went through treatments to get to this point and you deserve the recognition. Stand tall and walk with you head held high!! We'll all be with you in spirit.
Posts.Title: Going To My First RELAY FOR LIFE --- My UPDATE On How It Went! :)))))

Posts.Content: You are too funny.
Posts.Title: Charity Clothes Donation.

Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing your GOOD news with us!! I would be thrilled as well. Good luck to you as you continue your treatments, whatever they are. NED is the goal here and you'll be there sooner than later!
Posts.Title: And now for some good news!

Posts.Content: Pat, please know I am thinking about you too. Sending positive vibes your way!
Posts.Title: Definitely NOT Dancing With Ned

Posts.Content: Of course I remember you, you joined around the same time I did. Congrats on your NED status and wishing you luck on the final reconstruction. I, too, don't post often but I do come on here to check on my beautiful sisters. Glad you're back and doing well.
Posts.Title: Remember ME?

Posts.Content: Sue, I did my first (and only) walk last year. I was in the beginning of rads at the time. It was a very emotional situation and especially the survivors photo. Posts.Title: Going To My First RELAY FOR LIFE --- My UPDATE On How It Went! :)))))

Posts.Content: Sending ((((hugs)))) right back at you all!! Sue, thanks for echoing my thoughts, you do it so well! Love you all.
Posts.Title: Do you want to know something sisters in pink?

Posts.Content: Hi, 24, welcome to this site. I am not in the Mrytle Beach area but wanted to welcome you. We are here to answer questions, provide support and share our knowledge. Just ask away and we'll try to answer.
Posts.Title: new diagnosis - need info for Myrtle Beach area

Posts.Content: What wonderful pictures, thanks for sharing. I have to admit, I'd rather be sharing right there with you. You so deserve this wonderful vacation. Enjoy yourself and the "magic", too.
Posts.Title: new pix up

Posts.Content: Pitt, it was really good the hear from you. And, you are right, attitude is a choice. I have always been a very upbeat and positive person. I have tried to maintain that attitude throughout my treatments. At times, it hasn't been easy but I've forged ahead. I, too, have continued to exercise throughout my treatments. Some days are better than others but since the first of the year, I've maintained 5-6 times a week. I feel better and I firmly believe anything we do for ourselves and our attitudes, is well worth it!! Keep up the good work and keep us posted on your happenings. Take care.
Posts.Title: Facing forward - exercising again!

Posts.Content: I live in Atlantic Beach, northern Florida, actually the beaches of Jacksonville. I had the priviledge of meeting Jean when she was here and it was wonderful. I would love to meet some of my other sisters and would definately be interested in participating. Let's see who is interested and where they are located and plan from there. Sounds like fun!!
Posts.Title: Florida

Posts.Content: MamaG, I have no information either but wanted to let you know that I am sending (((hugs))) and positive vibes to you. I am certain they will determine the next course of treatment and once and for all kick this beast out!! How about we all take a trip to your Costa Rica home once this is achieved? Sending love your way!
Posts.Title: it's back again....... in my spinal fluid

Posts.Content: There are some very interesting screen names on this site and I just wondered what they mean and/or how they were created? When I finally found this site, I had already had my surgery but was still searching the internet for more information and with many questions. I stumbled upon this site and all along was thinking it's "my turn now" to deal with this disease. Hence, my screen name, my real name is Debbie. I'm interested to hear your stories. BUMP UP DATE 1/16/2011 I just reread all these stories and felt a little closer to you all. If you are new, tell us about your name. Enjoy!

Posts.Title: What's in your name?

Posts.Content: Linda, I, too, am impressed with your strength and tenacity. I remember hearing those dreaded words myself just a couple of months ago...Stage IV metastatic cancer. But, I am like you and taking it one day at a time. I wish you much success with the Xeloda and hoping that we hear from you soon that the cancer is not evident. I truly believe that a positive attitude has a lot to do with our well being. Sending strength and healing (((hugs))) your way. Take care pink sister!!
Posts.Title: Next step in my journey

Posts.Content: I am still laughing as I type this!!! Thanks for the daily humor!
Posts.Title: Back at the Ranch...

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed July 2009 and was 55. I'm the first one in my family to have bc, both my father's and mother's side. I also hope I'm the last, I have a sister and daughter, I hope they can be spared.
Posts.Title: age when diagnosed?

Posts.Content: Sunrae, we miss you on here. Let us know how you are doing. I am hoping you are just recovering and doing fine. Post when you can. Take care.
Posts.Title: Shout out to SUNRAE! How are you?????

Posts.Content: Candace, just to give you some comfort in the decision you made to have the mastectomy versus the lumpectomy.... I was dx in June 2009 with IDC and I opted for a lumpectomy. I also had chemo and rads. Just as I was scheduled for my first mammo post treatment, I noticed another lump in the same affected breast, just in another location. I had a recurrence in July 2010 and at the second dx opted for the bilateral mastectomy with 2 levels of lumph nodes removed. Thank goodness, they were clear. So, you did what you thought was right for you. I hope you never have to hear those words again but you need to stay vigilent with your self exams. This is a very frightening situation that I wish none of us had to ever endure.

Posts.Title: I Lost My Sister Today

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday, Rainbow4. Wishing you a day filled with plenty of cake and ice cream and lots of love and laughter with your family and friends. Also, wishing YOU many, many more and a year full of health and happiness!!
Posts.Title: Today is Rainbow4's Birthday!

Posts.Content: Candace, even when a bilateral mastectomy is performed, ALL breast tissue cannot be removed. So, the answer to your question, unfortunately, is that, yes, you COULD have a recurrence. Based on your test you mentioned that it showed an 8% chance for recurrence. This is very low. Your onc is recommending Tamoxifen because I am assuming that your cancer was estrogen fed (ER positive). I sincerely hope any "drama" will end for you and you can get back to Life After Breast Cancer. Take care.
Posts.Title: Is there a chance of reoccurence after double mast.?

Posts.Content: I am in shock. Life is so unfair. I am pissed off that this beast continues to wreck havoc on the lives of my Kindred Spirits not just once but years down the road. Claudia, I feel so bad for you. You are the epitome of grace and strength. I know you will beat this beast again, I'm just so sorry that you have to deal with it. Thank godness for your wonderful support system. They will get you through this along with the support of your Kindred Spirits here. We're with you all the way!!!

Posts.Title: Just when I thought it was safe to go back in the water, I was bitten by Jaws! So to speak...

Posts.Content: Ronda, just to give you a little more input, I finished rads on Christmas Eve last year. I did not have a "form" made either but rather I was positioned on my back with my arms criss-crossed over my head and I held onto a bar with both hands. The actual time to radiate was minutes. My rads onc recommended aloe as the only cream to use. I used it daily right after my rads and again before bed. I had 29 regular treatments and 9 boosters. I turned a little pink with the boosters but really did not burn. It has been almost a year ago and I still have my rads tan. Be sure to follow the instructions from your rads onc as they can all be a little different. Good luck to you, you will do just fine!
Posts.Title: Help I think I'm about to be a guinea pig

Posts.Content: I'll second that, Libby. I had a spinal tap prior to deliverying my daughter. Not fun, for sure!! Take care and thank goodness that's over, huh?

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to read that your father has passed away. I know how difficult it is to lose our parents. I lost my dad many years ago and my mother just 4 years ago. Be thankful that you got to spend time with your dad. Don't beat yourself up about your eating habits, just realize, as you have, that they have not been the greatest in recent weeks and do what you can to rectify that. You are coming down the home stretch and almost finished with radiation. That's a feat in itself. Take care of yourself and again, I am sending my heartfelt sympathy to YOU.

Posts.Title: When is Your Birthday?

Posts.Content: I agree with VickiSam and like she stated there are now laws that protect you. Symmetry after breast cancer is covered by insurance. Like Vicki said, go back to your insurance company to repeal this. It may also help to get your surgeon involved. Good luck. Let us know how it all comes out.
Posts.Title: Reduction surgery denied

Posts.Content: Hi, Traci, are we having fun yet?? I just read all the responses and it is amazing that every radiation oncologist seems to be different as to what type of cream to use. Mine recommended only 100% aloe. I get my radiaiation at 10:20 every morning so I don't use any type of lotion after my morning shower. Once my radiation is over, I do put on some aloe lotion when changing back into my clothes. I also put some on at night. I've only had 7 treatments so I haven't noticed anything yet. Good luck to you and keep us updated on your treatment and how it's going.
Posts.Title: Overachieving Rad Girl -- would appreciate advice from Rad Graduates!

Posts.Content: Traci, that is GREAT news. Yes, we LOVE good news, as you know. You could always take up driving the Pink Bus with all your spare time. There seems to be a need for it lately and with your personality, I think that would be awesome. Or, maybe just some extra time with Trace, now that would be enjoyable, too!! Thanks for sharing your good news.

Kimberly, I just wanted to welcome you to this amazing site. You'll find plenty of friendship, support, knowledge and just plain caring from this wonderful group of survivors. Ask anything you want and there will be someone that has experience in the matter. Glad you found us. Take care.

Posts.Title: Update BJmom

Posts.Content: I'm glad to read that you have decided to do radiation if it is recommended. Radiation is a localized treatment and is radiating the tumor site whereas chemo is systemic and is hopefully eliminating any rogue cancer cells in your body. I know you can do both and we will help to encourage and support you. Good luck and sending a (((hug))) your way!!

Posts.Title: An Indian with one testicle

Posts.Content: Kat, I had mine colored when I was 3 months out from chemo. I, too, was very salt and pepper, more salt than pepper. I had my hairdresser do the color and it came out beautifully. I thought it would also be very obvious when the hair was growing out but I haven't noticed it. I have it colored twice now and I'm looking forward to the day I NEED a hair cut. Not yet, though. Good luck and let us know how it turns out. P.S. Coloring my hair was just what I needed to shed the scarves and become "free". Do it, you'll love it!!

Posts.Title: Please just say a little prayer....

Posts.Content: This is for all of you wonderful individuals that are here to help and support us newbies. I had searched on-line for something just like this and was so happy that I finally found you all. This whole process is a very scary thing and it's been made more manageable by gaining knowledge from people who had been there. I feel like we can ask absolutely anything and there is always someone out there that can provide some knowledge or experience or just support if that's what's needed. It is truly amazing!! I, too, like to help people and can see myself on this board for a very long time. Once I'm finished with my treatments if I can help someone new get through the pain and answer some questions or provide guidance, I think I'll be there for support. Again, thank you for your support and caring!!

Posts.Content: Yes, the Miracle of Life!! Congratulations Auntie T!! I'm also trying to speak softly although this is cause for shouting from the rooftops. Thanks for sharing and hopefully you can get some sleep tonight.
Posts.Title: The Miracle of Life.... I just had to share...

Posts.Content: I haven't updated because I really don't have the treatment plan, yet. It has been a fun-filled couple of weeks worth of ups and downs. When I had a CT scan, it revealed a 1cm mass on my liver. Well, needless to day, I was surprised to hear those results. Then, I was scheduled for a liver biopsy. The preliminary as well as the final pathology concluded that it was a benign mass, I believe it was called an adenoma. I heard the work "benign" loud and clear and was elated. So, to be certain, I am now scheduled for a PET scan next Wednesday. The results of the PET will determine the route of my treatment. IF, and I'm being very optimistic here, it is clear, except for the breast, I will have surgery and then chemo. The chemo they are taking about is 4 rounds of AC and then 4 rounds of Taxol. There is the possibility that I may have radiation again, too. IF cancer shows up anywhere else, I will have chemo first and then surgery. So, like I said, I'm still in the testing stages. I must say that I am very impressed with the care at Mayo. I like the idea of MY team of doctors all meeting to discuss my personal situation. It is so different than my last 2 rounds with breast cancer. I keep hoping that the third time is a charm. I told one of my oncologists yesterday that I was amazed at how good I feel. I will continue to keep my positive outlook both on the inside and outside. I have a wonderful support group in not only my family and friends but ALL of YOU, too! I meet again next Friday with my oncologist and will be more knowledgable about my treatment plan. I told the oncologist on Friday that we need to get the show on the road because I have signed up for the 26.2 with Donna to be held in February. This is a marathon that will celebrate its 5th year next year. It was the vision of one of our local news anchor who is also a breast cancer survivor. 70% of the money collected for this event is presented to the Mayo Clinic for research. This has turned out to be a very substantial amount. The motto for Donna's race is to "Finish Breast Cancer". I only hope to be alive the day the announcement is made that a cure has been found!! I will keep you posted as I continue on this journey. I love you all and thanks for checking on me. Also, thank you for the emails and cards. This is a wonderful community and I am so happy I found you all 2 years ago!!
Posts.Title: How are you doing MyTurnNow?

Posts.Content: Traci, that is wonderful news!! Your sense of humor is once again shining through. It sounds to me like you get the double whammy.....a waltz with Ned followed up by the hokey-pokey with Nert. Enjoy your time, you certainly worked for it and congratulations, once again!!!!
Posts.Title: Hands off, girls -- NED is all mine today!

Posts.Content: I think like everything else in this journey, the "first" is the worst. Once you get through it and have your evening with NED you'll feel better. Can't wait to hear your good news! Sending positive vibes your way!!
Posts.Title: Say a prayer for me please...

Posts.Content: Libby is a true fighter. I am sending strength and healing vibes to you and your family. Keep fighting like a girl! We're all here in your corner. Love and (((hugs)))!
Posts.Title: Prayers for our Pinkflutterby

Posts.Content: Typically a lot of our oncs don't want us to even take the normal vitamins we were taking before dx. My understanding is this can affect the effectiveness of the chemo. My advice would be to go with the recommendation of her docs. The immune system will be compromised by the chemo. Does she also get the Nuelasta shot the day after chemo? This is given to help build the white blood cells.
Posts.Title: Supplements to strengthen immunity?

Posts.Content: Dee, I can totally understand your problems with losing your hair, eyebrows, etc. because that was the hardest part for me. Did you have chemo 17 years ago? It really doesn't matter one way or the other but I wondered if perhaps this was the first time to lose your hair. The words that mean the most to me from your post are "I want to try and live a normal life...". I read into that that you want to live. There are several ladies that are stage IV and perhaps they can provide some knowledge as to the journey based on this stage. There are some really nice wigs, scarfs, etc. that may help in your self image. I personally wore scarfs and ball caps. Bottom line, I wish you strength to accept what you will have to do to live your life as normal as possible. Sending (((hugs))) your way!! Stay strong sister.
Posts.Title: my family doesn't understand

Posts.Content: Christine, just wanted to welcome you to this group. I did not have the same surgery as you are but understand the fear of the unknown. As others have said, we're here and will be with you spiritually every step of the way. Good luck with your surgery and come back here often. Take care.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy in 5 Days - Having a Hard Time Coming to Terms/Accepting it Emotionally

Posts.Content: Laura, I'm also sorry to read that you have been so sick. I'm sending positive energy your way to help your body heal. Hoping for no dialysis, too!! Take care of yourself and keep us posted on your situation.
Posts.Title: Hey checking in just got out of hospital need prayers

Posts.Content: Laurissa, it's so good to see you posting. I don't have information about SSI but I know I've seen posts about it before. I'm sure one of our sisters will respond. It sounds like your treatments are rough. I'm sorry to hear this. Continue to nurish your body and just take care of YOU right now. I'm sending strength, love and (((hugs to you))) dear kindred spirit.
Posts.Title: stage 4 and disability

Posts.Content: A very Happy Birthday wish coming your way!! Have a wonderful day filled with cake, ice cream and plenty of presents.
Posts.Title: Thursday the 25th is Green Eyed Girls Birthday

Posts.Content: Sending positive energy your way!!
Posts.Title: Had my markers drawn today

Posts.Content: I do understand your fear. My husband has alzhelmiers in his family and I'm so concerned that he will also suffer from this down the road. I know the support we all receive in regards to our breast cancer from this site, is there perhaps a site for support of those diagnosed with frontal lobe dimentia? Just a thought. Know that you can always come here and receive encouragement and support from this group of amazing people. Continue to post and I hope your experience is not on the severe side. Remember, just like bc, all of the potential side effects suffered by individuals with this diagnosis are reported, doesn't necessarily mean you too will suffer from them. Good luck!!
Posts.Title: Anyone had a spouse diagnosed with temporal lobe dementia

Posts.Content: Yes, I had one last year after I completed lumpectomy, chemo and rads. I am a litle older than you, 56 (okay a lot older) and postmenopausal. My onc recommended it because I was going to begin taking Arimidex. I agree with you that that particular test was one of the easiest.
Posts.Title: Muscle Girls... was a Bone Density Test recommended for You?

Posts.Content: Sending a great big congratulations on grandbaby number 6. Enjoy your visit and have a safe trip. Please post some pictures when you can.
Posts.Title: Non bc celebration :-)

Posts.Content: Susan, a very Happy Birthday to YOU!! I, too, hope it is filled with family and friends as well as cake and ice cream and presents.....yes, lots of presents. Have a wonderful day and wishing you many, many years of good health and happiness!! Birthdays really do have a special meaning now, don't they?
Posts.Title: Today is Rague's birthday!

Posts.Content: Hi, Pat, it's good to hear from you as it has been a while. I'm sorry you are experiencing joint pain from the Arimidex. I have been taking it since 1/23 and I think that is around the same time you started. I am only noticing a hot flash or two throughout the day. I do recall my onc saying that IF I got any of the side effects that they would usually subside within 6 months. Good luck and let us know what you decide to do. I, too, have my first mammo next month and am getting a little apprehensive but I can't wait to hear you are NED. I'm keeping my fingers crossed for you and me. Take care.
Posts.Title: Arimidex.

Posts.Content: Congrats, Kickie on finishing chemo. I finished mine on October 15th and have a stubble now. Not hair, just stubble. I'm so looking forward to hair again, too.
Posts.Title: Last Chemo on Monday

Posts.Content: Barb, thanks for the update. We really do wonder how our sisters are doing when we don't hear from them. I hope you begin to feel better physically and real soon. So sorry to read about your friends. Try to remember the good times and rest and take care of yourself. Also, don't be a stranger. (((Hugs)))
Posts.Title: update on BJMOM

Posts.Content: Dawne, I remember all to well the first day of chemo. Mine turned out to be pretty noneventful, I hope yours is as well. Like my other sisters have said be sure to drink plenty of liquids. Let us know how you handle it and also know that we'll all be with you in spirit. Take care.
Posts.Title: First Chemo today

Posts.Content: Another good one. Thanks for the morning chuckle!!
Posts.Title: Gone Golfing

Posts.Content: A Happy and Healthy New Year wish to all of you wonderful survivors out there. My wish for the new year is for a cure for ALL the cancers out there. It may not happen but it sure doesn't hurt to wish for it!!! Take care everyone and be safe this evening!!
Posts.Title: I Just Want To Wish All Of You A Very Healthy & Happy New Year!

Posts.Content: What a beautiful gift to validate these extra special friends and their love for YOU!! It is so very important to have the support available to get through this journey and I'd say you have it in these very thoughtful ladies. Wear it with honor and keep us posted on your progress.
Posts.Title: I love my friends!

Posts.Content: Judy, best of luck on your surgery tomorrow. Wishing you a speedy recovery too. Take care.
Posts.Title: Prayers and Good Thoughts for your Surgery Tomorrow, Judy

Posts.Content: I haven't used that but not everyone loses their eyebrows and eyelashes. I never totally lost my eyebrows nor all my eyelashes, although they did thin. This didn't happen until probably 2 months after I was finished with chemo. They seem to come back in pretty quickly, too.
Posts.Title: Brian Joseph's Lash & Brow Gel???

Posts.Content: Hi, pdv, and welcome to the group no one wants to join. I had a needle biopsy after my diagnostic mannogram and sonogram. I was advised then by the radiologist that it looked like cancer but until the pathologist came back with the report, I wouldn't know for sure. Well, it was invasive ductal carcinoma and I then began the appointments and ultimate decisions regarding treatments. I had a lumpetomy, chemo and radiation. I just finished my treatments on Christmas Eve and have now started the 5-year pill Arimidex (my cancer was estrogen positive). It's all very overwhelming initially so I would suggest that you stop and take a breath and then take it one day at a time. We're a great group of very supportive and knowledgeable individuals and will be right there with you every step of the way. Keep posting and let us know your decisions. Take care and good luck!
Posts.Title: Just Had Sonogram and Scheduled to Talk With Surgeon

Posts.Content: Sunnie, that sounds normal to me. I also had a lumpectomy with a microscopic cell in the sentinel node. I received 25 regular and 9 boosters as my radiation treatment. If you are not comfortable with your suggested treatment, talk to the rads onc until you are. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Rads question...

Posts.Content: The hardest part of all of this is not knowing. The waiting game is no fun but unfortunately it's part of it. I don't think I ever considered just sweeping this under the rug, so to speak. I knew the seriousness of it and I have a husband and daughter and I wanted to live. So, I came to the realization very early on that I would do whatever I needed to do. You have an advantage over me and that is that you found this site in the very early stage. I didn't find these wonderful people until August and at that point I had already decided on the surgery and was in the middle of chemo. I had a hard time making the decision on lumpectomy versus mastectomy. My point is there are women and men on this board that have experienced any type of surgery and various regimes of chemo. We'll be here to provide our experiences and help in any way we can to help you make informed decisions. I'll continue to hope that you DO NOT have cancer and therefore can continue with your new life of RVing. The worst that can happen is you have to postpone your start date for a couple of months!! Take care.
Posts.Title: Just Had Sonogram and Scheduled to Talk With Surgeon
